page.title: 01Ettrick Valley
page.content: In this part of Ettrick Valley the river falls quickly from its source 3 miles away through narrow rocky gorges and running SW - NE. Due to heavy rainfall there can be a rapid rise or fall in water level. The land is mostly rough grazing for Blackface and Cheviot sheep with summer grazing for cattle. Large stretches of the hill on Nether Phawhope and over onto the southern slopes facing Eskdalemuir are planted with conifers There are two farms houses and one new holiday house, but there is evidence of early settlement at Over Kirkhope, site of an early Mediaeval chapel and village from the days when the lands of Ettrick Forest belonged to Melrose Abbey. The ancient forest, hunting ground of Scottish Kings was cut down to make way for the more profitable sheep
